caption: This museum shows the artifacts from the Indochina region. It has a really nice park next to it.  It takes around 1 hour to go around the whole museum and one can visit on one of the weekends if he tends to stay in Paris for a long time. I strongly suggest to book a ticket and be on time.

Visited the exhibition of 3 late Vietnamese artists and felt proud of Vietnam. The museum space receives a lot of natural light. There is a very large Buddha statue at the end of the tour and people can sit down to rest. It feels very peaceful.
I went to see the “Lê Phô, Mai-Thu, Vu Cao Dam” exhibition and it was really great. I didn’t have any wait when I went the morning I still recommend booking a ticket online first. Overall is great!

The Cernuschi Museum, a hidden gem near Parc Monceau, offers a captivating journey into Asian art through the remarkable collection amassed by Henri Cernuschi. Established over 125 years ago in 1898, this museum now holds over 15,000 artefacts, primarily from China and Japan, with additional pieces from Korea and Vietnam.  The vastness and diversity of the collection are astonishing, especially considering it stems from a single collector's dedication. The museum houses a comprehensive range of Chinese art, from archaic bronze pieces dating back to the 15th century BCE to intricate Tang dynasty ceramics and unique funerary masks from the Liao dynasty. The 18th-century Japanese Buddha of Meguro is a centrepiece among 900 objects permanently on display.  With free entry to its permanent collection and thoughtful accessibility features, this museum offers an exceptional opportunity to appreciate Asian art and history. A must-visit for anyone in Paris, the Cernuschi Museum is an extraordinary testament to one man’s passion for art and culture.

One of the must visit museum in the 8th arrondissement of Paris city. Its Asian culture history museums which is very richly of knowledge and heritage and their collections are just wow and beyond The Buddha statues in so many forms and size and the biggest one is gonna blowing your mind.
Very interesting Asian art collection - very well-curated.  What a wonderful gift to the City of Paris by a philanthropist....
awesome museum of Asian culture in Paris. Super worth (free btw) it

A beautiful collection of Chinese and Japanese artifacts, sculptures, ceramics and much more, spanning over centuries in the form beautifully curated displays. Free entry and right next to Parc Monceau in Paris’ 8th Arrondisement.

A beautiful museum full of life. The artistry is gobsmacking. Cernuschi’s love for Asian culture is inspiring and can be felt through his mansion! Its only weakness is organisational as it is confusing to follow the chronological route. Additionally, Musée Cernuschi is for everyone to enjoy as entry is free! Wonderful!

The museum is near the park Monceau, it has few rooms with mostly Chinese and Japanese art with pieces covering all centuries. Some artifacts are unique in Europe and the collection could be seen as the balance of the museum of Oriental art. The entry is free and there is a useful app well designed that allows to deeper the knowledge of many pieces and the history behind them. The is a small bookshop but not a cafeteria, better go to the nearby park if it's a warm day.

This museum is very discreet, few advertising but the exhibition are often of a very high level. The explanation and the presentation are also often very didactic. But overall, in the mater of finest art you will hardly found better than this museum. The last exhibition was about the evolution of drawing and calligraphy at the beginning of the twenty century in China. It was spectacular. It definitely worth a visit.
Nice, if a little small, exhibit of Asian art

I loved this museum, it's free and next to a beautiful park. It's not huge, but the layout is pretty great. It's mostly Chinese art throughout history with a tiny bit of other places sprinkled in. I love that it was ordered by time periods. You got to see pieces from most of the longer dynasties.

Small museum with little art collection, smaller than musée Guimet, but the advantage is that it is for free and you can go there if you are nearby parc Monceau. Staff is friendly to take your baggage and respond to any question. Nice to spend 15-30minutes. Also good to watch with kids.

It was a great experience to see the permanent exhibition for free. It was nice that all was arranged chronologically.   good info and good app were available to learn deeper. Very nice staff. Free vestiaire!
That was wonderful. I highly recommend this place.

For me (as an east Asian), it doesn't give me big impression even thought there is a giant Buddha statue but I visited there to see my favorite paintor's exhibition who is famous for his waterdrop paintings. And of course admission is free.
I just heard about this on Google. It's wonder and free. If you like Asian art, it's quite good. Some very interesting pieces. The park is quite nice also and just off the Metro.

Most museums in Paris would show some Asian collections. Two of them are 100% dedicated to Asia. One is this National museum Guimet with a larger collection including collections from west / central asia, Japan, Korea.There is a large collection from south east asia The other one is the Paris museum Cernushi. It is a smaller museum with fewer but higher quality collections. Any artifact is a must see. It focuses more on China and gives you a well done overview of China history.

Thursday, 23 March 2023 at 10:00 AM Art: 5/5 Excellent. Rooms 1-5 cover some beautiful Japanese art from the Edo (1603-1867) and Meiji (1867-1912) eras, and Chinese art during the Prehistoric (8000-2070 BCE), Ancient (2070-221 BCE) and Imperial (221-206 BCE) eras. There are some amazing examples of bronzes, jade, and porcelain items on display. I cannot wait until Rooms 6-14 open in August so I can view the remaining collections! Service: 5/5 Excellent. The security attendants and ticket desk were all kind, polite, and professional. Ambience: 5/5 Excellent. Fabulous atmosphere. You feel like you are entering the private collection of a rich eccentric uncle who traveled all over Asia. A beautiful 19th century private mansion turned into an easily-accessible museum. Cleanliness: 5/5 Excellent. The men’s restroom was spotless, the art rooms smelled fresh, and there was no visible dirt on the stairs. Value: 5/5 Excellent. How can you complain when the entry to the permanent collection is FREE?! Yes, anyone may enter without paying anything. Overall: 5/5 Excellent. A perfect score because I honestly could not find any fault. I am seriously impressed with this jewelry box of a museum.
What an incredible display of Asian art.  Totally worth visiting this museum, its never too busy to get in and get a great look at fabulous pieces of Asian art.
Small museum but with, an interesting selection of Japanese and Chinese antiques with emphasis on bronze figures and archaic food vessels. Big plus its free so worth a visit.
Discreet but brilliant museum. I haven't seen a lot of French museums with East Asian arts so visiting this was like a breath of fresh air!

A beautiful free museum in Paris that houses a beautiful collection of Asian works.  The Cernosky Museum, is a Parisian museum dedicated to Asian art, more specifically to those of the Far East: China, Japan, Korea and Vietnam, and is the second museum dedicated to Asian art in France and the fifth dedicated to Chinese art in Europe.  This museum was initially created thanks to a bequest of collections presented in 1896 to the city of Paris by financier Henri Czernosky. Opened in 1898, it is one of the oldest museums in the city. It ranks sixth among the municipal museums in Paris, and receives about 60,000 visitors annually. It is one of the fourteen museums in the city of Paris that has been managed since January 1, 2013 by the public administrative institution Paris Museums.
Wonderful collection of Asian art . Few masterpieces. Very well displayed.
Relatively small, but full with interesting artifacts. Nice excursion into Chinese history through ceramic and bronze objects

It’s a novel experience to visit a museum in a foreign country displaying collections of the culture where I come from. Its size and location are perfect for brief immersion in history and art. Most staff are benevolent, while a few guards somehow appear racist.

I really enjoyed visiting the Musée Cernuschi.  The staff was kind and helpful and the permanent collection is well described.  It isn't very big so quite easy to finish. The organisational structure of the exhibit was very helpful and I learned a lot about different Chinese dynasties.
A very good place for people who like Chinese and Japanese art. A very nice collection of Budas. And its os free.
Delightful museum right on parc monceau. Beautiful building! Lovely collection. And it’s FREE!

Admission is free. This is a hidden gem wedged between a neighborhood and a large park. French and English on signs. Some of the exhibits are closed from Jan-June/July but it was still really cool to see for free. Friendly staff.
Very calme, interesting museum near good park. Amazing collections from Japan, China.
If you have free time you should check this! Free museum with a vast collection.
Check the temporary exposition, which can be excellent! The regular museum is great allbeit small, but it is included for free
Interesting display of Asian arts.  Paid extra for the temporary exhibition only to find it all from the permanent collection which they could have shown anyway.

We were asked to leave because our 2 years old was happy and excited  by the guard who clearly got disturbed in his siesta. This is the opposite of promoting cultural knowledge! I was very shocked by the attitude and the lack of understanding!
There are several good Chinese or Asian exhits, worth a visit. However, I did not see those famous painting works due to no reservation, a little bit disappointed...
Located right next to Parc Monceau, this lovely museum is small but has quite impressive exhibition space. The hall with a big buddha is pretty cool.
